title: 111_hr2134
content: The Act may be cited as the "Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission Act of 2009". Congress finds that drug use in the United States is significant, with millions of users of marijuana, cocaine, methamphetamine, and heroin. The majority of cocaine and heroin in the US originates from Andean countries and Colombia and Mexico, respectively, leading to violence and corruption. Drug trafficking in transit countries poses a threat to law enforcement, political institutions, and national security. In Central America, Mexico, Venezuela, Ecuador, Haiti, and the Caribbean, drug trafficking fuels organized crime, threatening law enforcement, political institutions, and security. Drug-related violence is increasing in Mexico, with a significant number of deaths in 2008. Criminal networks traffic women and girls for sexual exploitation. Extremist groups like FARC and Hezbollah use drug trafficking to fund terrorist activities. Extremist groups in the Western Hemisphere, such as FARC and Hezbollah, use drug trafficking to finance terrorist activities. United States provided $11.3 billion in counternarcotics assistance to Latin America and the Caribbean from 1980-2008. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission is established to review and evaluate US policies on illicit drug supply reduction and interdiction, focusing on international drug policies in the Western Hemisphere. The Commission will identify options to improve existing counternarcotics policies. The Commission will review US policies on illicit drug supply reduction, interdiction, and demand reduction, focusing on international drug control policies in the Western Hemisphere. Key topics include assessing drug interdiction efforts, economic development alternatives, technology deployment against drug cartels, and efforts to curb trafficking of chemical precursors. The assessment includes better deployment of technology to target major drug cartels, efforts to curb trafficking of chemical precursors, United States drug certification process, population's demand for illicit drugs, drug prevention and treatment programs, and effective strategies for treating drug addiction and reducing societal harm. The Commission will assess the extent of illicit drug consumption driven by addiction, effective treatment experiences, recommendations to improve US drug policies, support for reducing drug supply and demand in the Western Hemisphere, and evaluation of success indicators in US drug control policy. Coordination with governments, international organizations, and NGOs in the Western Hemisphere will be conducted during the review. The Commission will consult with various leaders and organizations in the US, Latin America, and the Caribbean to assess the effectiveness of illicit drug control policy. They will also work with the Inter-American Drug Abuse Control Commission (CICAD) to identify ways to improve effectiveness. A report will be submitted to relevant committees within 12 months of the Commission's first meeting. The Commission will submit a detailed report to relevant committees containing recommendations, findings, and conclusions, including input from leaders and organizations consulted. The report will be made publicly available. The ONDCP report will include recommendations, findings, and conclusions from the Commission, as well as input from consulted leaders and organizations. The report will be publicly available. SEC. 6. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of ten members appointed by various leaders, excluding current government officials. Each member serves for the Commission's duration, with vacancies filled promptly. Appointments must be made within 30 days, and an initial meeting to plan the review process must occur within 60 days of enactment. The Commission shall hold an initial meeting within 60 days of enactment to select a Chairperson and develop a schedule for the review. Six members constitute a quorum, and members will receive travel expenses in accordance with regulations. SEC. 7. POWERS. The Commission has the power to hold meetings, conduct hearings, and access necessary resources from various government agencies to carry out its duties. The General Services Administration will provide office space and administrative support for the Commission's activities. The Commission has the authority to use the United States mails and enter into contracts for necessary activities. The General Services Administration will provide office space and administrative support for Commission activities. SEC. 8. STAFF. The Commission shall have an Executive Director who can appoint staff and experts as needed, with compensation not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. Staff appointments are exempt from certain provisions of the United States Code. The Executive Director of the Commission may procure temporary services and detail government employees to assist in carrying out duties without affecting their civil service status or privileges. Authorization of $2,000,000 for the Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission without fiscal year limitation. Commission terminates 60 days after report submission to Congress.
